content: The Act titled "Improving Economic Sanctions Act of 2016" establishes an Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group. The "Improving Economic Sanctions Act of 2016" establishes an Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group within the Department of the Treasury to report directly to the Secretary of the Treasury. The "Improving Economic Sanctions Act of 2016" establishes an Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group within the Department of the Treasury. The Group's membership includes the Undersecretary of the Treasury for Terrorism and Financial Crimes as chairperson, and senior representatives from various offices and bureaus of the Department of the Treasury. The "Improving Economic Sanctions Act of 2016" establishes an Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group within the Department of the Treasury, including key offices like the Office of Foreign Assets Control, Office of Intelligence and Analysis, Office of Terrorist Financing, and Financial Crimes Enforcement Network. The Group conducts contingency planning for imposing economic sanctions under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. The "Improving Economic Sanctions Act of 2016" establishes an Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group within the Department of the Treasury to conduct contingency planning for imposing economic sanctions under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. The planning considers the vulnerability of the foreign country or entity to sanctions and the effectiveness of different types of sanctions on their economy. The Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group considers factors such as the impact on the foreign economy, the feasibility of imposing sanctions, effectiveness of unilateral vs. multilateral sanctions, and the process for lifting sanctions. The Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group will review and improve economic sanctions programs administered by the Office of Foreign Assets Control. The Group shall submit annual reports to Congress, including an overview of interagency coordination, consultation with policy experts, and a comprehensive sanctions impact assessment. The report may also include a classified index and closed briefings for specific congressional committees. The comprehensive sanctions impact assessment required under paragraph (1)(A)(vi) may use various research methods and must evaluate each economic sanctions program administered by the Office of Foreign Assets Control. The report must include an assessment of the impact of sanctions on the economy of the foreign country or entity, the impact on the US economy, and any behavioral changes in response to the sanctions. It should also include details of the social scientific research methods used for each assessment. The report submitted under this subsection will be publicly available on the Department of the Treasury's website, excluding classified information.
